DataSetTools.dataset
Class XScale

java.lang.Object
  DataSetTools.dataset.XScale
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
GeometricProgressionXScale, UniformXScale, VariableXScale
public abstract class XScale
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

The abstract root class for "X" scales used in data objects.

Version:
1.0
See Also:
DataSetTools.dataset.Data, UniformXScale, VariableXScale, Serialized Form

Method Detail

getInstance

public static XScale getInstance(float[] x)
Returns an XScale with the specified x values. If the x values are uniformly spaced, a UniformXScale is returned, otherwise a VariableXScale is returned.

Parameters:
x - The array of x values used to generate the XScale
Returns:
If the entries in x[] are evenly spaced, return a UniformXScale corresponding to those x values, otherwise return a VariableXScale. If the array x[] is empty or null, this returns null.

getStart_x

public float getStart_x()
Get the starting "X" value

Returns:
the first x value in this XScale

getEnd_x

public float getEnd_x()
Get the ending "X" value

Returns:
the last x value in this XScale

getNum_x

public int getNum_x()
Get the number of "X" values

Returns:
the number of points in this XScale

inRange

public boolean inRange(float val)
Determines if the specified "X" is within the range of the Xscale.

getXs

public abstract float[] getXs()
Returns the array of "X" values. The array will have num_x entries. For a UniformXScale object, the values will be uniformly spaced. For a VariableXScale ojbect, the values may be arbitrarily spaced, as specified when the object was constructed.

getX

public abstract float getX(int i)
Get the ith x-value from this XScale.

Parameters:
i - The position of the x-value that is needed. This should be between 0 and the number_of_x_values - 1.
Returns:
The x value in position i in the "list" of x-values for this x scale. If there is no such x value, this will return Float.NaN.

getI

public abstract int getI(float x)
Get the position (or index of the LUB) of the specified x-value in this XScale.

Parameters:
x - The x value to find in the "list" of x values represented by this x scale.
Returns:
The position "i" in the list of x-values, where the specified x occurs, if it is in the list. If the specified x is less than or equal to the last x in the "list", this function returns the index of the first x that is greater than or equal to the specified x. If the specified x value is above the end of the x scale, the number of points in the x scale is returned. This is the index of the Least Upper Bound (chosen from the list of values in the XScale) for the specified x_value.

getI_GLB

public int getI_GLB(float x_value)
Get the position (or index of the GLB) of the specified x-value in this XScale.

Parameters:
x_value - The x value to find in the "list" of x values represented by this x scale.
Returns:
The position "i" in the list of x-values, where the specified x occurs, if it is in the list. If the specified x is greater than or equal to the first x in the "list", this function returns the index of the last x that is less than or equal to the specified x. If the specified x value is below the start of the x scale, -1 is returned. This is the index of the Greatest Lower Bound (chosen from the list of values in the XScale) for the specified x_value.

extend

public abstract XScale extend(XScale other_scale)
Constructs a new XScale that extends over the smallest interval containing both this XScale and the specifed XScale. The points of the the current XScale are used, except for any interval covered by the other XScale and NOT covered by the current XScale.

Parameters:
other_scale - The x scale that is used to extend the current XScale
Returns:
A new XScale of the same type ( Uniform or Variable ) as the current XScale is returned. The new XScale covers the union of the intervals covered by the current XScale and the other XScale. See the subclasses for specific behavior.

restrict

public abstract XScale restrict(ClosedInterval interval)
Constructs a new XScale that is the restriction of the current XScale to the intersection of the ClosedInterval and the interval of the current XScale. If the intersection is empty, this method returns null.

Parameters:
interval - the interval the XScale is restricted to.
Returns:
A new XScale of the same type ( Uniform or Variable ) as the current XScale is returned if the intersection is non-empty, or null if the intersection is empty.

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object other_scale)
Compare this XScale to another one. Unless the two scales are genuinely the same object the method returns true quickly. Otherwise the method is written to speed up returning false.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Print the range and number of X values in this x scale

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

Print

public void Print(java.lang.String message,
                  int mode,
                  int num)
Print part of all of this XScale, depending on what print mode is specified.

Parameters:
message - text message at start of printout
mode - integer flag BEGINNING, MIDDLE, ENDING, SOME or ALL
num - number of elements to print, in cases BEGININNG, MIDDLE or ENDING.

Test_GetXsGetX

public static int Test_GetXsGetX(XScale scale)
Verify that the points returned in an array by getXs() are the same as those returned by individual calls to getX().

Parameters:
scale - The XScale to test
Returns:
the number of points where errors occured.

Test_GetXofGetI

public static int Test_GetXofGetI(XScale scale)
Verify that getX(getI(x)) == x for every point "x" in the XScale.

Parameters:
scale - The XScale to test
Returns:
the number of points where errors occured.

Test_GetI_GetI_GLB

public static int Test_GetI_GetI_GLB(XScale scale,
                                     int num_points)
Verify that getI(x) and getI_GLB(x) return correct values for a collection of randomly generated "xs" in the interval [start_x-1, end_x+1]. For values in [start_x, end_x] this requires that getX(getI_GLB(x)) <= x <= getX(getI(x)).

Parameters:
scale - The XScale to test
num_points - The number of random values to generate
Returns:
the number of points where errors occured.
